Following its meeting on April 27, 2022, the government announced a set of measures at a press conference to help families with children cope with high inflation and rising energy prices. The specific assistance consists of paying (.pdf) a one-time contribution of 5 thousand crowns per child to all families with an annual income of up to one million crowns.

At a press conference, CNN Prima News editor Dáša Šamanová asked (video, time 30:11) Minister of Labor and Social Affairs Marian Jurečka whether the contribution is calculated from gross or net annual income. While asking the question, he leaned over (time 30:31) to Prime Minister Petr Fial and apparently asked him something. Petr Fiala responded by shrugging his shoulders and smiling.

Marian Jurečka answered the question (video, time 32:00): "If I'm not mistaken, in the debate we had about that parameter, we were talking about the net income of that household."

He later corrected this original information on April 30, 2022, saying that it would be a threshold of CZK 1 million gross. He posted the change on his Twitter account , where he apologized for the inaccuracy.

SECTION B:

The former government introduced several programs to help employees, businesses, and the self-employed (SVČ) during the Covid-19 pandemic.

As for the current compensation programs, the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs includes , for example, the Antivirus A and Antivirus B programs. The purpose of the first of these is to compensate employers whose employees were ordered to quarantine or isolate. Antivirus B was to compensate companies if they had to limit operations due to a significant number of employees in quarantine, or, for example, if demand for their services or products is limited due to the pandemic.

For injured self-employed persons, but also for partners of small companies and people working on the DPČ and DPP, there is a Compensation Bonus program, which falls under the Ministry of Finance.

For example, the Ministry of Industry and Trade was supposed to be responsible for the COVID 2021 subsidy program and the COVID Uncovered Costs program, intended for companies with a significant drop in sales. Although they were already prepared, the government ultimately decided not to relaunch them.

Let us add that there are currently some programs whose purpose is primarily to provide entrepreneurs with loan guarantees , but these are not classic compensations. We can mention, for example, the COVID Sport guarantee program under the Ministry of Industry and Trade. It also managed the recently completed COVID Travel Agency Guarantee program for travel agencies, which was followed by the Travel Agency Guarantee program of the Ministry for Regional Development.

The above information shows that compensation programs are indeed divided primarily between the three mentioned ministries. We therefore assess Marian Jurečka's statement as true.

SECTION C:

Context

Minister of Labor and Social Affairs Marian Jurečka is talking about a possible decision by the Constitutional Court (ÚS) regarding the newly adopted reduction in pension valorization in June 2023. The ANO movement is currently working (video) on a complaint (or a proposal to repeal the law) with which it wants to challenge the amendment to the Pension Valorization Act. The SPD movement also wants to join the submission.

Let us mention that due to the newly adopted amendment to the law, which was also signed by President Petr Pavel, during the extraordinary valorization of pensions in June, pensions will increase on average by only CZK 760 ( .doc , p. 1). According to the previously valid rules , the average pension should have increased by CZK 1,770 . According to the government , the change is necessary because without the adjustments, the “ public finance deficit would have increased by more than CZK 34 billion” this year. The government now expects that pension spending will increase by only CZK 15 billion ( .doc , p. 5–6).

The opposition cites several reasons for submitting the proposal to the Constitutional Court. The first is the so-called retroactivity (.pdf, pp. 2–3), or retroactive effect. The opposition movement claims that in the case of the amendment, the change in the legal regulation was approved only after the valorization mechanism was launched. " We believe that it was created on January 31," Alena Schillerová justifies retroactivity as one of the pillars of the prepared proposal, because the amendment only entered into force after the aforementioned date, specifically March 20, 2023.

The second reason for submitting a motion to repeal the amendment is the state of legislative emergency declared by the government, due to which the submitted government proposal is being discussed in an abbreviated session. According to Act No. 90/1995 Coll., on the Rules of Procedure of the Chamber of Deputies, such a state can be declared in an extraordinary moment " when the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens or the security of the state are fundamentally threatened or when the state is threatened with significant economic damage ". The opposition wants to refute the government's argument that the state of legislative emergency was declared precisely because of the risk of "major economic damage", as it believes that this was unjustified.

Opposition parties can submit a proposal from March 20, when the amendment was published in the Collection of Laws . According to the chairwoman of the ANO parliamentary group, Alena Schillerová, the proposal could reach the Constitutional Court in early May. The movement's deputy chairman, Radek Vondráček, said on March 19 that this could happen within a month.

After considering the proposal, the Constitutional Court then decides whether the law or its individual provisions are in conflict with the Constitution. If the constitutional order has been violated, the court may annul the law in question (in this case, the amendment to the Act on Lower Pension Valorization) and order the relevant state body to restore the situation prior to the violation of the Constitution. However, in the past, although the Constitutional Court did not consider a decision to be unconstitutional, it published an obiter dictum , which is a non-authoritative statement beyond the basic reasoning ( .pdf , p. 11).

Finding to declare a state of emergency

Marian Jurečka mentions the case law when the Constitutional Court found doubts about the method of extending the state of emergency. This happened, for example, in March 2021. At that time, the Constitutional Court was considering a proposal by a group of senators to annul the resolution of the government of Andrej Babiš (ANO) due to the declaration of a state of emergency at the request of the governors, which occurred immediately after the proposal to extend the previous state of emergency was not passedby the Chamber of Deputies .

The Constitutional Court rejected the proposal ( .pdf , p. 1) stating that it was not within its competence to decide on such a proposal (.pdf, p. 7. 12). However, as an obiter dictum , it stated ( .pdf , p. 7) that " a state of emergency cannot be 'newly' declared by the government from the moment the 'authorized' state of emergency has ended and the Chamber of Deputies has not agreed to its extension ". As part of the obiter dictum , the Constitutional Court can therefore submit a non-binding statement ( .pdf , p. 11) or a recommendation for the legislative process.

Let us add that in the debate with Minister Jurečka, the moderator asked about option B in the event that the Constitutional Court "swept away" the amendment, that is, if it recognized it as unconstitutional, and thus ordered the government to restore the status quo before the violation of the constitutional system. In such a case, the situation described by Marian Jurečka, that the Constitutional Court would not "change the essence" of the amendment, would not occur. Since the decisions of the Constitutional Court are binding , the amended law would have to return to its original form.

Finding on the amendment to the pandemic law

In 2022, the Constitutional Court ruled ( .pdf ) in a similar case, where a group of deputies led by Radek Vondráček (ANO) challenged the use of a state of legislative emergency to discuss an amendment to the pandemic law (Law No. 39/2022 Coll.) at the beginning of 2022. In September 2022, the Constitutional Court rejected the proposal of the opposition deputies ( .pdf , p. 1), but in its ruling it stated (p. 24) that "the process leading to the adoption of Law No. 39/2022 Coll. cannot be considered - at a sub-constitutional level - to be flawless" and noted in passing that "the legislative process under review and its course can be considered a reflection of the current political culture, the state of which is characterized, among other things, by numerous obstructionist negotiations, the chaotic agenda and course of meetings, as well as the inflexibility of the legislative process".

Final evaluation

Marian Jurečka truthfully states that in the past, when rejecting proposals to repeal a law, the Constitutional Court used non-binding statements, so-called obiter dictums, in which it found, for example, doubts in the legislative process. For this reason, we assess the statement as true.

Marian Jurečka, together with a group of deputies elected for the KDU-ČSL, submitted a proposal (.pdf) for an amendment to the Pension Insurance Act on March 29, 2019. The explanatory report contains a total of 12 proposals, of which 10 proposals concern widow's pensions, students and mothers' compensation.

The proposals regarding widows' pensions are as follows:

  • "It is proposed to ease the requirements for the deceased spouse's insurance period by 5 years for entitlement to an old-age pension as a condition for obtaining entitlement to a widow's and widower's pension."
  • "It is proposed to extend the minimum period of receiving widow's and widower's pensions from 1 year to 5 years."
  • "It is proposed to bring the threshold before retirement age for permanent receipt of widow's and widower's pensions closer - from 4 to 8 years before reaching retirement age."

  • "It is proposed to increase the percentage assessment for widow's and widower's pensions, from the current 50% to 80% of the percentage assessment of the pension to which the spouse was or would have been entitled at the time of death."
  • "It is proposed that if the conditions for entitlement to payment of disability and widow's or widower's pension are simultaneously met, the percentage assessment of both pensions is paid in full and half of the percentage assessment is paid from the other pensions, unless the amount pursuant to paragraph 1 is higher."

The proposals for compensating mothers are as follows:

  • "In order to quickly partially correct the unfairly low pensions of mothers (or fathers in a substitute role) who contributed to the pension system by caring for and raising children, [it is] proposed to increase the percentage assessment of the old-age pension by CZK 500 per month for each child raised."
  • "It is proposed to reduce the mandatory insurance period to 10 years for obtaining a pension entitlement after reaching retirement age . " According to the explanatory memorandum, this may apply, for example, to mothers of multiple children who lack a replacement insurance period.

SECTION E:

In his statement, Minister Jurečka describes the mechanism of extraordinary pension valorization, which, according to the Pension Insurance Act, will be used in the event of rapidly increasing inflation.

The conditions for increasing pensions in an extraordinary period are specifically described in Section 67. According to it, an extraordinary valorization of pensions is applied if the growth of the consumer price index has reached at least 5%. The merit part of the pension (i.e. the percentage assessment of the pension) is then increased by the same percentage as the price increase.

The period for determining price increases always begins with the calendar month following the end of the period according to which pensions were last valorized. In the case of a regular valorization date, price increases are monitored until the end of June of the previous year (in the case of a regular date in 2022, this would be the end of June 2021). However, in the case of an extraordinary valorization , the assessed period is shortened and ends with the month " in which price increases reached at least 5%. Let us specify that these 5% must be the sum of "month-on-month inflation increases " for the given period.

Pensions are increased on a regular basis from January 1. The last increase took place on January 1, 2022, based on the increase in the consumer price index by the end of June 2021 (.pdf). The last month "taken into account for pension valorization" was June, not July, which Marian Jurečka mentions in his statement. However, let us note that the period for determining price increases for further pension increases begins in July 2021.

The whole issue is also explained in a press release ( .pdf ) of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs from November 18, 2021. According to this report, pensions must be increased by a government decree if the above conditions are met. The government must issue this within 50 days of the end of the month in which prices increased by at least 5%. If the estimates come true, according to the ministry, the pension increase should take place in June 2022 (.pdf).

In January, the spokesperson for the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs , Eva Davidová , also commented on the extraordinary valorization of pensions for the daily Právo: " We assume that there will be such a price increase in January that the cumulated inflation from July 2021 will exceed five percent and that the valorization will be carried out in an extraordinary period, which will include the entire price development until January 2022." She also added that the regular valorization of pensions in 2023 will be lower than if the extraordinary valorization had not occurred, but overall, both pension increases will reflect the overall price development.

As for the overall growth of the consumer price index , from July to November 2021, this value increased by 3.1% . In December, there was a month-on-month increase of 0.4% , bringing the total number to 3.5%. The Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs is therefore likely counting on an even faster increase of at least 1.5% in January, to a total of 5%.

Let us add that the Ministry of Finance, in its January macroeconomic prediction, expects a relatively sharp increase in the average inflation rate to 8.5% in 2022. According to information from the Czech Statistical Office, in 2021 it was 3.8% .

Given that Marian Jurečka describes the applicable rules for extraordinary valorization correctly, apart from a minor time inaccuracy, we assess this statement as true.

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

At the outset, it should be clarified that Chairman Fiala is talking about Act No. 236/1995 Coll. (abbreviated as the salary of constitutional officials). The so-called automaton , or linking the salary of constitutional officials to the state of the economy, is reflected in the determination of a certain coefficient by which the so-called salary base is multiplied. This is 2.75 times the " average nominal monthly salary of natural persons in the non-business sphere achieved according to published data from the Czech Statistical Office for the calendar year before last " . In other words, for 2019, the salary base is calculated as 2.75 times the average monthly salary for 2017 and determined by the communication of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs.

The above-described machine itself was already part of Act No. 309/2002 Coll., on amendments to laws related to the adoption of the Act on the Service of Civil Servants in Administrative Offices. At that time, the salary base for representatives designated by the Act was to be three times the average monthly wage for the year before last. The purpose of this establishment was actually to establish a " stable link between the salaries of constitutional officials and the development of wages in the non-business sphere " (.doc, p. 36). The procedural history of this provision then consisted primarily in the several postponements of the effectiveness of this act or the annulment of individual provisions of the Act on the Salary of Constitutional Officials by the Constitutional Court. The final amendment to Act No. 359/2014 Coll. from 2014 comes (.pdf) from the pen of Jan Hamáček, the then Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies. The original government proposal (Bohuslav Sobotka's government) envisaged (.pdf) a fixed salary of CZK 52,248 for the next four years, and in the end, Hamáček's amendment was accepted instead.

The new salary range was thus determined by determining a new multiple for deputies (2.75) and a special multiple for judges (3.00). Given the difference between the fixed amount for 2014 and the amount given by the multiple in 2015, Hamáček's proposal provided for a gradual annual increase in the multiple over four years. The salary base should thus reach 2.5 times the average wage for the year before last in 2018.

Petr Fiala and the entire ODS did not vote for either Hamáček's amendment or the final wording of the law . The majority abstained, and in the second vote two deputies were against. Therefore, the expression " we agreed " used by Chairman Fiala in his statement is somewhat questionable.

As for the meaning of the statement about " creating a solution that we will not have to return to ", the amendment may directly imply an effort after 2018 (when the salary was calculated by a multiple of 2.5) to immediately jump to calculating with a multiple of 2.75 in the following year. According to data from Czech Television (infobox note), however, such a procedure would cause the salary of a deputy and senator to increase by 14,700 CZK. The government, which proposed an amendment to the Act on the Salaries of Constitutional Officials, is probably aware of this. It should (.pdf, p. 3) permanently reduce the multiple for the calculation back to 2.5 and also change the average that will be multiplied.

It was also the ODS's votes that moved the proposal from the first reading to committees, which means that the Chamber of Deputies, including the ODS, will consider this proposal and will return to addressing the salaries of MPs, thanks to the ODS.

To summarize the assessment, the timing of the adoption of the amendment is appropriate, but the intention not to return to discussing salaries does not follow from the ODS's vote so far, which concerns the new government draft amendment (the discussion took place on November 15, 2018).

One of the points of Babiš's pre-election Treaty with the citizens of the Czech Republic was a sharp stance against migration quotas. It is also important to mention that no party in Czech politics expressed support for the quotas set by the European Union for accepting migrants. Slovakia, Hungary and Romania also expressed their opposition to quotas within the European Union. At the moment, the tendency is changing and, according to the proposal of the Visegrad countries, so-called flexible solidarity in migration policy could be adopted. Individual member states would then have the opportunity to decide for themselves whether to accept refugees or whether their assistance would be financial.

Illegal migration, i.e. legal entry into our territory but exceeding the permitted period of stay, has had a downward trend in recent years . However, these data are of a general nature and are in no way related to the refugee crisis, in which the Czech Republic was not and is not a destination country for refugees.

The truth remains that Andrej Babiš outlined priority points in his election campaign entitled Contract with the Citizens of the Czech Republic and defended himself against migration. However, this text cannot be considered the basis for changing migration policy within the European Union. There were many initiatives and pressures in the EU to change quotas and migration policy, and the Czech Republic was also critical of quotas. The biggest supporters of quotas were the countries that were most affected by the migration wave - Greece, Italy , Germany and Austria . However, even within them, the quota policy is being abandoned.
